President Jimmy Carter announced the breaking of diplomatic ties with Iran as a result of the Iran hostage crisis of 1979-1981.
The U.S. Embassy becomes a training ground for the Revolutionary Guards Corps.
Mohammad Reza died in exile in Egypt, where he had been granted political asylum by Egyptian president Anwar Sadat.
Iraq invades Iran after years of disagreements over territory, most notably the Shatt al Arab waterway.
Iraqi forces launched air strikes on Iranian air bases, following up with a ground invasion of the oil-producing border region of Khuzestan.
When Iraqi President Saddam Hussein announces his intention to reclaim the Shatt al Arab, an eight-year war breaks out.
Following negotiations mediated by Algeria, the U.S. hostages are released after 444 days of captivity.

After a leak by Mehdi Hashemi, a senior official in the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps, the Lebanese magazine Ash-Shiraa exposed the arrangement that facilitated the sale of arms to Iran, the subject of an arms embargo.
An American navy ship, the USS Vincennes, shoots down an Iranian civilian plane, killing all 290 passengers and the crew.
The United States later apologizes and agrees to financial compensation for the victims families, saying the civilian plane was mistaken for an attacking military jet.
Iran accepts United Nations Security Council Resolution 598, leading to a cease-fire in the Iran-Iraq War.
